comments.commentBody:
Dearest Deadline, You capped-off Saturdays XWDP by thanking your fellow "Cruciverbiphiles" for having brightened up your day with smiles, not to mention the fact we appreciatively tossed beau coup bouquets of reco's at your divine feet.
However, despite all of the tributes that were posted for your inspired bit of poetry, did you have to go and rub our noses in it by coining a new word as well......see Cruci-whatever above! :-)
You say we made you smile, but you not only brought smiles to our collective mugs in return, but made our regular visits to WP even more wonderfully enjoyable than ever!

Howie, Librarose & Co. Still standing and applauding!

It's less important as to whether Mitt Romney enters the electoral fray equipped with an economic rationale of skewed wealth distribution, offered by the Republican mouthpiece Conard, or that of Zingales, presenting capitalism with human face, than perhaps to address an impossible task of erasing the nightmarish memories of the Bush era economic disaster and financial collapse from the voters' mind. Against this, the task of Obama seems relatively easier, as he can perhaps assure the voters that though, his promise of fixing the economy might well have not remained fully met, but at least, he did what he could to put back the economy on track, despite repeated Republican obstructionism. The same perhaps could be said about Obama's achievements on the foreign policy front. It's thus easier to convince the voters that however uncured their economic woes might have been, but unlike his Republican predecessor, Obama at least lent a healing touch to them, though that can't be a justification for his sub-optimum performance, which he should promise to improve next time.
Here are some highlights from the closing win over Horsens.

Well. The silence on the Goal blog comment thread is deafening. Here are a couple of questions. First, does anyone have links to any highlights of the clinching game that's referenced in this article? It's always cool to see a team lock down a title when it's not expected. Second, does Parkhurst have any chance of replacing Cherundolo as the USMNT right back? They're both getting up there in years, but Dolo more so. I haven't followed Parkhurst closely, but could he be a viable option at right back in the coming WC cycle?
Here are some highlights from the closing win over Horsens.

"... depending on how Republicans define 'conservative.'"

Republicans' key constituent is the coal and oil industry. Even if they were to abandon the pro-life stance, anything that harms that key interest will be way off-table.

Therefore, there should be absolutely no hope whatsoever that Governor Romney takes a stance against "Drill Baby." The Kochs, for one, are spending tens of millions of dollars in this election only for Mr. Romney to turn against them? No way.

You seem to want a benevolent dictator. Whether it is President Obama, President H Clinton, President Warren or President Stein in the White House, the President does not write legislation and s/he does not pass laws. S/he can only sign into law and enact (or not enact as Reagan managed to do) the legislation that Congress passes.

I wish President Obama had the political skills of LBJ, who managed to get Congress to act. But in my history of following politics, I have never witnessed a more solidified Congressional opposition to a president. I don't think even LBJ could have gotten these Republicans to vote yes on bills he supported.

The Republicans who vowed in 2008 to take this president down at any cost to the nation are traitors. Yet, like you, most Americans will still blame the President for not doing what he could not do and they will reelect the traitors. Really, do you think President Warren could cut the defense budget?

Many will choose to support a third party candidate, hoping that by some miracle someone, perhaps a woman, who is neither a Democrat or a Republican will float above the Constitutional restrictions on the office and mandate a better world. The reality remains, either a Democrat or a Republican will be elected president. A Republican president with a Republican Congress and a Republican Supreme Court will get you to as close as you can get to the dictatorship you seem to want.
"defined as a wimp"?  Maybe in your world, but certainly not in mine.
and how long have you been a Yankees fan/Mets hater, Mr. Free?

I remember 1969 just well enough to imagine that this no-hitter could be a similar catalyst this season to what Seaver's near-perfect game was in early July of that year...

Imagine...

"The Mets may be the best in town for the next decade?!" HAHAHAHA! The season is 1/3 complete and they have played well but the Mets may be the best in town...FOR THE NEXT DECADE?! Give me a break!

"Much more fun and better baseball than the big money team across town." If fun and better baseball = haven't won a WS in over a quarter of a century, then yes...the Mets are a lot of fun.

"The Mets may not have a big bank account but they have young talent on the field and more talent in the minors. The Yankees have neither." Huh?? Yankees have neither but they make the playoffs almost every year whereas the Mets talent gets them nowhere. I guess young talent means watching the post-season on TV almost every year.

The greatness of Wise's catch cannot be overstated. It was an exceptional athletic feat. And considered in context -- the 9th inning of a perfect game, which he had just entered cold off the bench -- it's up there with the greatest baseball catches ever. Mr. Wise's winning personality makes remembering that game all the more enjoyable. I hope to see him in action late in a game this November.

JolleyG, The erudition that routinely flows throughout WP would floor the likes of Shakespeare, Coleridge, Mill, Macauley, Voltaire, Goethe and Einstein combined!
A day doesn't go by that I don't thank the good god that made me that I am welcomed to sup at the same table with such amazingly accomplished members of society, both here and abroad.
Surely you didn't think I'd leave suejean and Viv, and now Rebecca of Istanbul, out of the conversation... did you? :-)

WHH

My wife fully agrees. Prepare for a doctor's appt as though it were an important business meeting. Make an agenda. Do your homework. Be straightforward and have your note taker write down what the doc says. If you don't have a note taker, take a tape recorder. Really. It's important.

Wrong. Doctors' incomes have not gone up just like CEOs. Physicians in insurance networks have either had the exact same fee for decades or the fee has gone down every year for the at least the last 5 years. I am a provider and have experienced it myself. I earn less every year from patients who use insurance. Each year I add only five dollars to my fees for patients who do not use insurance. So do some research before you blame doctors.

Wow, great advice. I do everything but the last. But now I will aways ask -"Do you want to go first or do you want me to go first?"

The other thing I always do to is call my Dr's by their first name. I shake their hand and say, "Hi 'firstname', nice to see you."

I'm glad that works for her.  My own experience is similar to those in the article.  Being assertive and/or asking about alternative to a doctor's recommended treatment is often met with at a minimum a steely glare  coupled with stony silence, or at worse overt anger for "challenging" his/her expertise.  And don't tell me just to find another physician.  I have tried that...a number of times.  The patients' fears of retribution in this article are also well-founded, e.g., refusing to provide me with copies of my medical records. Yes, of course, that is against the law, but that doesn't seem to be much of a deterrent for some docs.

"This blog post and the Health Affairs article provide an important glimpse at the challenges health care providers face when it comes to involving patients in their own care decisions..."

I think you missed the point of this article. The problem is the doctors who do not want to involve pateients in their health care rather than patients who refuse to become involved. The subjects in the study cited had graduate degrees! One might make a reasonable assumption that they were articulate and intelligent, yet they FEARED the negative reaction of their doc's so greaty that they were largely silent. The FEARED their doctor might even exact retribution. What does this tell you about their doctors?

Let me pose an alternative hypothesis:  Perhaps the problem is not the patient's feelings of vulnerability (if indeed they exist), but rather the refusal of the doctor to take the patient's questions and concerns seriously.
@Nancy.  You know what?  If these doc's don't think they're making enough money, they should do us all a favor and get out of medicine.

Wow.  What arrogance.  These day's most middle class individuals and families feel fortunate to have any kind of health insurance, no matter how meager it is.  Many pay huge annual deductibles in addition to a significant share of the real cost of the premium.  And most of these plans are HMO's.They cannot afford "condierge" medicine.  In many cases, they can't afford the deductibles of their plan.  Most importantly, they should not have to pay "concierge" rates for basic health care. I don't know what la la land you live in, but it's not the U.S.A.

@EC. You were treated shamefully. I suggest you file a complaint in writing with your health insurance company about this doc and ask that you be allowed to see another PCP because this doc refused to address your symptoms.  It's worth a try.
@Diana.  Try reading a post before you reply to it.  Colleen did not write that the doc received a reimbursement of $800.  She stated the doc charged $800.
Simple. Because so many doctors are not as you describe yourself.

Seems like Diana has poor reading comprehension.  Bnc wrote that tardiness dyskinesia was a SIDE EFFECT of the medicine prescribed, not that the medicine was being prescribed to treat dyskinesia in the first place. Bnc did not mention wha condition was being treated.  So we actually cannot know if the condition can be effectively treated without drugs.  Diana, your arrogance and willingness to quickly draw wrong conclusions makes me grateful you are not my doctor (assuming you even are one in the first place-- I suspect you are not, frankly).

When I was diagnosed with cancer, I headed to one of the nation's best cancer centers for treatment. Sure, I asked by physicians questions, but the reason I went there was the depth of experience the physicians had. I was never presented a smorgasbord of treatment options, nor did I want such a choice!

I'm a PhD-level scientist at a university, who has access to electronic journals. I have read dozens of articles about treatments for my cancer. I have no problems understanding the articles. But all that reading is no substitute for the three plus decades of experience my oncologist, a world-recognized leader, has.

On the flip side, I do think, as with any profession, there are poor physicians. Patient-centered care will do nothing to alleviate this problem, however.
